column2: Someday the Nets will come in from the cold. When they were winning American Basketball Association championships as the New York Nets, they pointed out that they were in the in the wrong league, where Dr. J did marvelous things for the edification of too many empty seats in Nassau Coliseum.

ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, (AP)--No man can put his money into the bank on Bin Zayed Street, and a police guard will stop him if he tries. The small bank on the edge of this Moslem sheikdom is for women only, and in this Arabian Gulf oil state their accounts can run to a million dollars and more.

MAPUTO, Mozambique, Feb. 22 (Reuters)--Erich Honecker, the East German head of state, arrived here today for a three-day official visit and was welcomed at the airport with full military honors by President Samora Machel Mr. Honecker has also visited Libya, Angola and Zambia.

TAKASHIMADAIRA, Japan--Recently a 26-year-old man plunged to his death from the top of an apartment building in Takashimadaira. He was at least the 40th person to commit suicide by jumping from a high story at this huge complex of apartment buildings on the northeast outskirts of Tokyo since it was built in 1972, the largest apartment block in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--After five weeks of sporadic debate and compromise in which little other substantive legislation could be considered, the Senate tonight sharply curtailed the controversial tactics that have been used in recent years to keep filibusters going after cloture has been invoked.

Cargill Inc. announced yesterday that it would build a sunflower processing facility on a 42-acre site in an industrial area of Riverside, N.D., at a cost of about $18 million. It said that the complex was the first in the nation specifically designed to process sunflower seeds into oil.
Washington, Feb. 22 (Reuters)-- The Government plans to establish a new method of pricing gasoline next month that would increase the cost by 2 cents a gallon, Energy Department sources said today.

Douglas Dunn is a protean choreographer. His dances are forever changing shape. They change so much that, even though they all have individual titles, one sometimes wonders whether they have individual identities.
LONDON Just before last Christmas it so happened that I wanted to say a prayer. I stifled the temptation.

In the biggest monthly inflationary surge since the recession summer of 1974, consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area rose 1.1 percent in January, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 23--Turning their backs on Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's direct order to stay away, 70,000 to 80,000 Iranians attended a rally today staged by the People's Fedayeen, an extreme left-wing organization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- President Carter is expected to spend next Friday night with a Mexican-American family when he visits Los Angeles for a Democratic fund-raising dinner.

SHOHOLA, Pa., Feb. 23--The mystery of a chef's identity--a conundrum posed this week by a New Yorker magazine profile of an anonymous culinary genius who was said to create magnificent meals at an unknown restaurant somewhere within 100 miles of New York City--was solved last night.
A 47-year-old midtown pizza-parlor owner was charged with homicide yesterday after a man he shot for harassing him died at St. Clare's Hospital, the police reported.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 23 (AP)-- Rhodesian planes bombed a black nationalist camp 22 miles west of Lusaka today in what the Rhodesian Government said was its continuing effort to prevent guerrillas from sabotaging elections scheduled for April.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23-- With no place to go but up after finishing last for two years, the New York Mets assembled their pitchers and catchers for spring training today and even scored a victory: a labor arbitrator upheld the management in a salary dispute with Dale Murray.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 23 (AP)--Braniff Airways paid a $100,000 fine here today stemming from Federal criminal antitrust charges against Braniff and Texas International Airlines for trying to block service of a Texas commuter airline.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 (AP)--City negotiators offered a blanket amnesty today to 1,100 striking policemen in an effort to end a strike that has disrupted the Mardi Gras celebration and garbage pickups. The strike is now threatening to spill over to the city's port, the nation's second largest in tonnage.
Nina Simane made her first appearance in a New York nightclub in 10 years on Thursday evening at the Village Gate, and she made it in what has become typical Nina Simone fashion.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23--If a consumer can buy Chivas Regal for about the same price as Scorsky Scotch why not have the best," said a spokesman for a private labeler, Jay Ambrose of Santa Monica, Calif.

A star was born in Madison Square Garden last night. Her name is Canzetta Young, but Candy will do just fine; she is 16 years old, lives in Beaver Falls, Pa., and set a world indoor record in the women's 60-yard high hurdles.

BANK certificates of deposit with high yields and issued in the short-term Euromarket, normally available only to big corporations or in stitutional investors, are now available to small savers as well.

The 600 or so people sipping champagne and nibbling hors d'oeuvres and raw vegetables beneath the vaulted ceiling in the marble lobby of the Woolworth Building on lower Broadway Thursday night weren't there to toast George Washington's birthday (he would have been 247).

The price of home-heating oil in the New York metropolitan area has risen nearly 20 percent since the fall, from about 50 cents a gallon to 60 cents, an increase that will cost an average homeowner at least $100 this year and will add $200 million to the fuel bill for the entire metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--American and Chinese merchant ships are scheduled to begin sailing between Seattle and Shanghai without waiting for the United States and Chinese Governments to resolve legal issues or to negotiate a maritime treaty, officials here disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)--One of the engineers involved in the head-on collision of two trains in Alabama last Sept. 18 is probably to blame for the crash, in which three persons died, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.

The thinking fighter thinks too much, Mike Rossman was saying. When he has a match coming up, Mike said, he fights it out in his head too many times. Going to sleep at night, he fights it out, Mike said, "and on the road and walking down the street and in dreams and at the blackjack table."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Federal Trade Commission withdrew its opposition today to the sale of a Columbus, Ohio, glass plant to the Lancaster Colony Corporation, also of Columbus.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 23--The terrain on which the Vietnamese defenders are meeting the Chinese invaders is mountainous, remote and closed to foreigners. The Governments involved have never felt an obligation to tell their own people or the world what they are doing and what is being done to them.

A New York City transit policeman who shot and killed a 17-year-old girl during a struggle with a suspect on a crowded Herald Square subway platform was cleared of any wrongdoing yesterday by a Manhattan grand jury.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Chicago Cubs sent Manny Trillo, the second baseman, and two other players to the Philadelphia Phillies today in an eight-player trade.

ALBANY, Feb. 23--Citing the "apparent inability of the National Administration to come to grips with" oilprice increases, New York State's Energy Commissioner, James L. Larocca, today ordered a full-scale investigation into the pricing and supply policies of six major oil companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23--Benson Ford Jr., a part owner of the Ford Motor Company and a nephew of Henry Ford 2d, the company's chairman, will be arraigned on drug charges Monday in a municipal court in San Francisco.
OTTAWA, Feb. 23 (AP)-- Canada announced today that it would produce $50 gold pieces for trading on the world gold markets.

GENEVA, Feb. 23--After exchanging views here for two weeks, the people who know more about climate than anyone else in the world have concluded that climate's future trends can be predicted in a meaningful way only after "an interdisciplinary effort of unprecedented scope."

The dollar fell against all major foreign currencies except the Canadian dollar and Dutch guilder yesterday, amid worries over the Chinese bombing of Vietnam. Trading on the world's foreign exchange markets in New York and abroad was described as light.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)--The arrest of four farmers during a demonstration at the White House today prompted the police to ban any further tractor convoys through the streets of Washington.
And now, for his retirement years, Paul O'Dwyer thinks: Why not bring down Jimmy Carter?

HARTFORD, Feb. 23--Governor Ella T. Grasso disclosed today details of a proposed constitutional amendment to limit state spending. But she acknowledged that because of legislative opposition, the proposal was not likely to be enacted this year.

The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble was formed in 1974 to develop performance skills in promising students at Mr. Ailey's American Dance Center, to bring dance to dance-deprived institutions and towns along the East Coast and to develop new choreographers.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 23--The hardest part of getting anything accomplished in Iran these days is finding out who has the authority to approve it. There is such a vacuum throughout the country that power is falling into the hands of anyone who has the daring and strength to seize it.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 23--Fighting continued near the Vietnamese provincial capital of Lang Son today as the Chinese invading army maintained its heavy pressure on Vietnamese defenders, Western analysts reported. An analyst said that Lang Son was probably in Chinese hands.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (AP)--A man and a woman swooped into a Montreal shopping center today aboard a hijacked helicopter, held up a bank and then made their getaway by air and subway, the police reported.

LONDON, Feb. 23--England was a smuggler's paradise for a day as customs officers stopped work today for 24 hours, along with thousands of other white-collar civil servants, in a bitter dispute over pay.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 (UPI)--Domestic car sales by the Big Three auto makers dipped slightly in the middle of this month, with the Ford Motor Company reporting the only gain over the corresponding period a year ago.

TOKYO, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Finance Ministry said today that it would lift restrictions on foreigners' purchase of Japanese bonds, effective tomorrow, ending emergency measures to limit flows of speculative short-term funds into Japan.

GENEVA, Feb. 23--The new Iranian Government has called for the freezing of all assets in Switzerland of the exiled Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, and members of his family, the Swiss Foreign Ministry said today.

Perhaps because I am an outsider, I can sympathize with the statement by Pope John Paul II to the Latin American bishops that the Roman Catholic Church's mission is "religious and not social and political."

Bruce Mason, the protagonist of Wallace Stegner's "Recapitulation," is a retired Ambassador. In returning to Salt Lake City after an absence of 45 years, he becomes an ambassador in reverse, someone going backward into his own country to negotiate there for peace and amicable relationships.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UPI)--Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that he was optimistic Iran would soon resume the sale of oil to the United States, heading off the likelihood of a serious energy shortage or other business crisis this year.

Heating-oil prices first started climbing last fall, after a year and a half of relative stability. Oil analysts said then that the sudden spurt was merely a catch-up round of increases traceable to the steadily rising costs that heating-oil dealers had been absorbing all along.

Mother-daughter dressing isn't what it used to be. The idea now is to match not the clothes but the label--if, that is, Mother is the type who wears Yves Saint Laurent, Anne Klein or Cacharel. All three are now making little girls' clothes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--While Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, was inviting officials of the Environmental Protection Agency earlier this week to resign if they were disgruntled, President Carter was telling the head of that agency that he was very happy with its work, according to Administration officials.
The New York City Opera and an ally celebrated some anniversaries at the opening of the company's spring season on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.
ATHENS, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Greek Government froze prices at year-end levels today and adopted several other restrictive measures in an attempt to prevent a sharp increase in inflation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)--Kurt W. Muellenberg, the head of the Justice Department's organized crime division, will join the General Services Administration Monday as acting special counsel, it was announced today.

TOKYO, Feb. 23--A complex struggle between the United States and Japan over the procurement practices of the giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, which places orders worth $3 billion a year, is reaching a crucial stage.

Chief Martin Duffy of the Manhattan Detective Area appealed yesterday to the public to report to the police any information that might help solve the murders of seven persons, whose bodies were found in a Harlem apartment last Tuesday night.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23-- Stringing together three birdies over the last five holes, Jane Blalock carded a six-under-par 66 at Pasadena Golf Club today to match a course record and take a two-shot lead after the opening round of the 26th annual Orange Blossom classic.
Anna Lord Strauss, a former president of the National League of Women Voters and a prominent supporter of various civic groups, died yesterday in her New York City apartment. She was 79 years old.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 23--India's economy has slowed despite a sharp increase in industrial production.

BROOKHAVEN, Miss. (AP)--Robert Earl May Jr., a 14-year-old who pleaded guilty to four armed robbery charges and, without ever being tried, was sentenced to 48 years in prison wish no chance of parole, was granted a trial and freed on bond today after serving a month in prison.

WILMINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 23-- Sepp Ferstl, the 25-year-old Alpine racer from the tiny village of Rupolding--near Berchtesgaden--completed today a West German sweep of the two United States downhill skiing championships.

A faint echo of the Jimmie Lunceford Orchestra, one of the more distinctive big bands of the 1930's and 40's, can still be heard in the Rainbow Room on the 65th floor of the RCA Building, where Al Cobbs's eight-piece band is playing for dances this week and next, Tuesdays through Sundays.

Efforts by the Nixon Administration to control public broadcasting, purge it of commentators considered hostile to the President and reorganize it so it might serve the Administration's aims are detailed in newly disclosed documents from files of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy for 1969 to 1974.
A court order that imposed a racial quota on the hiring of firemen in Bridgeport, Conn., was dismissed yesterday by a Federal Appeals Court that questioned the "sweeping affirmative relief."

DETROIT, Feb. 23--The Chrysler Corporation, its new-car sales still trailing those of a year ago, announced today the early retirement of Robert K. Brown, executive vice president for sales and marketing, the company's highest-ranking sales official.

Since the Ivy League title and the automatic berth in the National Collegiate tournament had already been secured by Penn, Columbia set its sights on a bid to the National Invitation Tournament last night and scored a 64-52 victory over Princeton in Levien Gymnasium.

The Unitrode Corporation, a maker of semiconductor devices, said it had commenced its litigation against the Dynamics Corporation of America and Rooney Pace Inc., a New York brokerage firm, in connection with Dynamic's acquisition of a 9.7 percent interest in Unitrode.

By their very nature, concerts of contemporary music tend to be chancy affairs, containing as much, if not more, dross than quality. The last two programs presented by the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music in Carnegie Recital Hall had their fair share of marginalia, but several works did stand out as being a bit special and well worth any open-minded listener's attention.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Chief Justice of India's Supreme Court will investigate corruption charges against members of the families of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai and Deputy Prime Minister Charan Singh, the Government announced today. The ruling Janata Party and the opposition have been debating the issue for months.
Christopher Durang is one of our leading stage practitioners of collegiate humor, and sometimes he does it wonderfully well.

When Herbert B. Evans, the state's new administrative judge, was a student in the late 1930's at DuSable High School on Chicago's South Side, he was appalled that low-cost housing in the neighborhood was segregated.
The plunging price of stock of the Polaroid Corporation cast a pall over the entire market yesterday as virtually all sectors staged a retreat.

The Lincoln National Corporation said it was "disappointed" with the rejection Thursday by the American ReInsurance Company's board of directors of Lincoln National's proposal to acquire American Re-Insurance.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (UPI)--Steve Durbano, the defenseman for the St. Louis Blues, was suspended for five games, and the Nick Fotiu of the Rangers was fined $300 today for a stickswinging brawl that cleared both benches in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last Wednesday.

Top-seeded Staten Island scored the first 10 points of the second half to break open a close game and defeat Brooklyn College, 77-61, last night in the City University basketball tournament semifinals at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP)--A Federal jury has awarded $617,536 to the mother of a 19-year-old Bucks County woman killed by an Upper Moreland police officer when he was on duty Jan. 4, 1977.

WASHINGTON AMERICANS, who are familar with fingernail polish, are now promised a coating that will maintain the natural color and luster of their front teeth. Stewart Lustgarten, an officer in the Boston office of a dental supply company, will receive a patent next week for the material and method of application.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. Feb. 23 (AP) --Fifty policemen lobbed tear gas into a second-story motel room early today to rout two men suspected of murder, abduction, rape and robbery across 100 miles of coastal South Carolina.

DEVA, Spain, Feb. 23 (UPI)--Terrorists presumed to be Basque separatists; shot a federal policeman to death when he stopped his car at a crossroads today. It was the 24th terrorist slaying of the year in Spain.

The former Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas had a favorite religion anecdote: He was flying on plane that was hit by lightning, and as the aircraft pitched and wobbled none of the passen gers knew what to do.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--A year and a half after beginning an overhaul of the way it handles cases, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has significantly reduced its backlog of 135,000 cases and shortened the average time for conciliating job-discrimination disputes from two years to 65 days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--With relations between Saudi Arabia and the United States already strained, Crown Prince Fahd has canceled plans to come to Washington next month amid conflicting explanations for the decision.
Gold futures ended this week's trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York at $253.70 an ounce for the March delivery, up from $248.60 a week before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--A recent decision by the United States Court of Appeals here has challenged a Federal rule that permits utility companies to charge customers in utility bills for taxes the companies have not yet paid.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Feb. 23 (AP)--A $150,000 advertisement display featuring a bikini-clad model extolling the glories of vacations in the frozen North has raised the temperatures of Alaska legislators and feminists.
TEL AVIV, Feb. 23--In a small, cramped room at Tel Aviv University, Aharon Yariv busily analyzes the military and strategic problems facing Israel. He confesses that his mood is gloomy.

For the first time in the six-year history of the Grand National Team Championship, Long Island has outnumbered New York City in the qualifying stage of the event. The Dance Theater of Harlem, directed by Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook, swept in an array of new works by a disparate group of choreographers Thursday night at the City Center-55th Street Theater.

Syria's chief delegate to the United Nations denied yesterday that members of the Jewish community in his country were persecuted. He accused Zionist groups of spreading such reports to divert attention from recent charges that Israel had abused Arab political prisoners.

The Dravo Corporation and the Southern Industries Corporation announced they had signed a definitive merger agreement whereby Southern Industries will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Dravo. The companies had previously reached an agreement to merge.
James F. Capalino, the 28-year-old director of Mayor Koch's Community Board Assistance Unit, was named by the Mayor yesterday to the $54,000-a-year post of Commissioner of General Services.
Exacta wagering was added to the program at Aqueduct yesterday as negotiations resumed in the labor dispute between the New York Racing Association and its unionized parimutuel clerks.

The postmaster general for the Northeast region said yesterday that his inclination "at this moment" was to keep the regional headquarters in New York City rather than move it to New Rochelle and that his staff had narrowed their search for suitable office space here to one "preferred building."

HANDY WORK The Museum of Modern Art's current display of 24 pieces created by Jackie Winsor, the young sculptor, has been called an important exhibition by art critics. As a supplement to the show, this morning at 10 o'clock the museum is presenting the artist in a discussion of her work, a lecture especially geared for students and teachers.

Military sources in Washington, Tokyo and at NATO headquarters in Brussels believe that the Chinese Army has missed its chance for a quick and relatively cheap victory in Vietnam, largely because the irregular Vietnamese forces on the frontier evaded a major encounter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Treasury Department said today that $378 million was raised yesterday by selling 1.5 million ounces of gold at record prices.

The Allstate Financial Corporation said it had filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of $50 million of senior notes due March 15, 1986. The notes are not redeemable before March 15, 1984.

City Commissioners, Councilmen and municipal employees will begin driving 450 physically handicapped children to school Monday in an expanding program that is scheduled to continue until a wildcat strike by school bus drivers ends.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23 --To the surprise of virtually everyone but himself, Don Gullett threw a baseball for 15 minutes today. He simply walked into the Yankee camp, picked up a baseball and actually threw it, in the bull pen at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23--The National Park Service today withdrew the permit granted for a Nazi rally this Sunday at Independence Mall Historical Park.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)--President Carter honored Jesse Owens, the Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. and 15 other elderly blacks today for their contributions to society.

Allen Ginsberg, the poet, was awarded the National Arts Club's Medal of Honor for Literature in a ceremony Thursday evening at the organization's house on Grammercy Park South.
James P. Richards, former United States Representative from South Carolina and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, died Wednesday. He was 84 years old and lived in Lancaster, S.C.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23--The hottest new course at Yale this term is not taught by a famous scholar. The 84 enrolled students receive no credit. There are no term papers. The course is auto mechanics.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 23-- The United States called in the Security Council tonight for a cease-fire in the fighting in Indochina and urged the parties involved "to move the dispute to the negotiating table."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Consumer prices rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today. The sharply higher prices indicated that the Administration's efforts to retard inflation had so far failed.

WARSAW, Feb. 23 (Reuters)--Two American citizens who were injured in a gas explosion that killed 49 people in a Warsaw bank last week are "doing all right" in a hospital here, a spokesman at the American Embassy said today.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 23-- Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, flying to Peking for an official visit, said today that the Carter Administration believed it could "lay the foundation" for normal economic relations with China despite the fighting between Chinese and Vietnamese troops.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23--During a round of competition the orthodox golf professional looks as if he is undergoing root-canal dentistry combined with a stomach-pumping operation. He usually gives the impression he would rather be elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Last month's rises in food prices, which accounted for nearly a third of the increase in the January Consumer Price Index, were attributed today to sharply higher prices for beef, fresh fruits and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--President Carter is prepared to match any Soviet restraint on strategic weapons if the Senate refuses to approve a new strategic arms limitation agreement, the White House said today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 23 (AP)--A Federal district judge ruled today that Planned Parenthood, a nonprofit corporation that operates an abortion clinic in St. Paul, cannot be denied state money for pre-pregnancy family planning services.

After a six-year hiatus, North and South Korea have resumed their "peace" negotiations. Even as Chinese troops smashed into Vietnam, representatives of the two Koreas met at Panmunjom. They shook hands and exchanged polite greetings for the benefit of photographers, and then held a meeting whose most important agreement was to hold another meeting on March 7.

HUNTINGTON, Utah, Feb. 23 (UPI)-- A short, chubby holdup man wearing a cowboy hat entered the Zions First National Bank and killed two tellers today. A Federal Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday found a 63-year-old New Yorker guilty of threatening to blow up a New York-to-Geneva Trans World Airlines jet last Aug. 28 unless Rudolf Hess, Sirhan Sirhan and others were freed from prison. No bomb was ever found.

If Boys and Girls High School's basketball team wins the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn championship tomorrow against Alexander Hamilton, it can be assured of three things--having a berth in the city-wide semifinals, having the best-dressed coach, and having its cake and eating it, too.
HOUSTON, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Continental Oil Company has announced the start of the first commercial production of crude oil in the South China Sea.
State Supreme Court Justice Arthur C. Aulisi died Thursday at his home in Gloversville, N.Y. He was 71 years old.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23--Several of the Soviet Union's top military leaders spoke out strongly today against China's invasion of Vietnam but carefully avoided any suggestion that Moscow might retaliate.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska (UPI)--An earthquake measuring 4.6 on the Richter Scale shook east central Alaska just before midnight yesterday. No damage was reported. Seismologists at the University of Alaska's Geophysical Institute said the epicenter was about 10 miles outside of Fairbanks.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23--Organized labor is modifying its tactics in an effort to improve its weak showing on the political and organizing fronts. Chris Schwenk, the son of the former Suffolk County Republican leader, Edwin (Buzz) Schwenk, drowned Wednesday while swimming near the exclusive Sao Conrado Beach district in Rio de Janeiro, a family spokesman said yesterday. He was 26 years old.

TOKYO, Feb. 23 (AP)--The Soviet Embassy in Peking canceled a party scheduled for tonight, saying it did not want to entertain officials of Chinese invader forces, Japan's Kyodo news service reported.

Allyson Brackett Bass and Dr. Walter A. Boyle 3d were married yesterday at Brockway Springs, a resort at Lake Tahoe, Calif. The Rev. Alfon W. Larson 3d, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Thomas McMahon Jr. of Kenilworth, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Elizabeth McMahon, to Willard Carlisle Butcher, a widower of Wilton, Conn. Heavy fighting was reported in northern Vietnam yesterday around the provincial capital of Lang Son, which increasingly appeared to American and West European intelligence analysts to be the strategic prize sought by the invading Chinese troops.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it had developed a device that could substantially reduce the amount of energy consumed by electric motors.

John R. Vogel Jr., executive director of the New York Power Pool, which coordinates the operations of the state's eight major electric utilities, died of cancer Monday at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady at the age of 54. He lived in Guilderland, a suburb of Albany.

In past business cycles, the housing industry was used to make the economy cool off. Interest rates were raised higher than the ceilings that savings institutions were permitted to pay, and housing funds flowed elsewhere. That was considered unfair, and the system was changed alter the money crunch of 1979 to make housing bear less of the burden.

New Federal regulations will cause a typical four-person welfare family in New York City to lose about $10 a month in food-stamp benefits starting today, with similar losses upstate, according to state and city officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Carter will shortly have before him an "Iranian response plan" comprising 13 to 15 immediate executive actions that can be taken to help overcome the oil shortage caused by the halt in petroleum imports from Iran, according to Administration officials and industry representatives here.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 28--Not long after Rod Carew arrived here to begin swinging the bat for the California Angels, he drove his Porsche to a foreign-car repair shop for an estimate on a slipping clutch. The price was $700, which seemed expensive to him, especially when another Porsche owner mentioned that the same job had cost him only about $400 recently.

KUWAIT, Feb. 28--The Oil Minister of Kuwait, which has raised oil prices by a larger amount than any other country in recent weeks, warned today that world supplies would probably remain tight throughout this year, presaging a total price rise by the end of the year that is likely to exceed the 14.5 percent agreed upon last December by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

"BECAUSE this is an electronic machine, I have been able to give it a new topology," explained Mario Bellini, the Italian furniture and industrial designer, referring to the new Olivetti ET 221 electronic typewriter. "This is the lowest professional typewriter ever produced," Mr. Bellini continued. "I've tried to stay away from the mechanical look and to give the machine as flat a profile as possible."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--The Social Security Administration disclosed today that it had been unable to credit nearly $69 billion in wages to the correct workers' accounts because of identification problems dating to 1937.

EVERY year when temperatures drop below freezing, many homeowners and apartment dwellers are plagued with the problem of windows and sometimes doors that "sweat," or drip water on the inside. Even windows with storm sashes, which should prevent this, sometimes "sweat."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a contract requiring a manufacturer to pay a royalty for the right to market a new invention remains enforceable even it the invention itself is later denied a patent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Congressional Black Caucus told President Carter today that it intended to mobilize public opinion to fight his proposed reductions in social welfare programs.
Donald Burr, a singer, actor and director who appeared in many Broadway shows, died Tuesday at Lyons (N.J.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and had lived for many years in Long Valley, N.J.

BETHESDA, Md., March 1 Results of some long-awaited experiments to gauge the risks of gene-splicing research were made public today, and they indicated virtually no hazard in the specific type of work involved.

THE PENNSYLVANIA BALLET, now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Sunday afternoon, looks as fit as a fiddle this season. The dancing is tauter and more polished than ever. The company acts as if it were being exposed to new challenges.

The number of major crimes reported in New York City declined last year, with most neighborhoods showing a drop in the crime rate, according to statistics made available yesterday by the Police Department.

Physicists at the Carnegie Institution in Washington have reported that they have made a new form of hydrogen that is a transparent, ice-like solid at room temperature. Three persons were indicted yesterday on Federal charges involving cocaine sales in Manhattan. Both sides in the six-day-old milk strike agreed to resume talks through mediators today, but the latest in a string of violent incidents and friction continued to cloud prospects for a quick settlement.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 1 Resorts International won the first Atlantic City casino license, and two other giants of the gaming industry, Caesars World and the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, expect to be next unless Fiore Francis (Hi-Ho) D'Addario, a brash newcomer to the casino business, has something to say about it.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 6 The graybearded mullah works in a partitioned-off corner, signing documents and stamping them with a seal as he talks on the telephone.
PARIS, March 6 (AP) More than 800 Moslems were killed in the sub-Saharan country of Chad over the weekend by groups of black youths, Government officials reported today in Ndjamena, the capital.

IT was a typical Sunday at the Galtymore House. At one end of the room, John Doran and his wife, Barbara, were talking with friends about the baby they were expecting "any day now." Nearby, two customers were arguing, briefly, over the odds at the track, then, at greater length, about the relative merit of serving mint jelly with lamb. In the back, a small crowd played darts.

GREENVILLE, S.C., March 6 Textile unionists fighting to sew the union label on the giant J.P. Stevens Company textile operation announced plans today to intensify their campaign of "corporate isolation" against Stevens by stepping up pressure on its financial allies and on major Stevens stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 6 A leading nutritionist told the Federal Trade Commission today that, among all the food products sold through television advertising directed at children, candy, cookies and presweetened breakfast cereals were the most likely to cause tooth decay.

ATLANTA, March 6 (AP) Tom McMillen sank a pair of free throws with 1:28 remaining and when Julius Erving missed two shots in the final minute, the Atlanta Hawks held on to edge the Philadelphia 76ers, 94-91, tonight.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 Baseball will open its spring training season of 346 exhibition games tomorrow, but the balls and strikes will be called by local umpires at each site because of a contract dispute between the bid leagues and their men in blue.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 6 Billy Carter was admitted today to a special unit of the Long Beach Naval Hospital for treatment of alcohol abuse.
DENVER, March 6 (AP) Houston's Moses Malone blocked George McGinnis's shot as the final horn sounded tonight, preserving a 119-118 victory for the Rockets.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 6 Ron Franklin had been saying all week there was "no way" he could get Spectacular Bid beaten, but the young jockey almost found a way today in the $200,000 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the loss of oil from Iran might force the United States to dip into its Strategic Petroleum Reserve for the first time to bolster supplies of heating oil for next winter.
The dollar scored some late gains in foreign exchange trading, in New York yesterday after moving lower earlier in the day on currency markets in Japan and Europe.

WOLFSBURG, West Germany, March 6 (AP) Volkswagenwerk A.G. today introduced a six-year warranty against rust on the bodies of its automobiles sold in Europe. "The buyer of a new Volkswagen or Audi model is expected to bring in his vehicle for inspection after two and after four years," the company said.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 6 A jury of four men and two women was empaneled here today in the case of Karen G. Silkwood, a 28-year-old plutonium worker who had been a persistent critic of safety conditions at the Kerr-McGee Corporation's plant in Cimarron, Okla., where she was employed when she died in a mysterious automobile accident more than four years ago.

PEOPLE of taste who dote on Moroccan cooking tend to find it among the most sensual foods on earth. It is without question one of the world's 10 great cuisines. A steaming platter of perfectly ordained couscous, to some palates, is about as close as one need come to feasting on heavenly manna.

LOS ANGELES, March 6 The earthquake that began for Columbia Pictures Industries with the David Begelman scandal 14 months ago has ended with the appointment of 48-yearold Frank Price as president of Columbia Pictures.

The National Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel producer, announced an agreement yesterday to acquire for $240 million all of the common stock of the United Financial Corporation of California, the holding company for the nation's 11th-largest savings and loan assocation.

Construction contracting in 1979 is expected to total $154 billion, 3 percent below a cyclical peak reached last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company. Despite the shortfall on the 1978 showing a record $158 billion volume this year will still represent strong construction demand, the report noted.
Cattle futures, which reached historic highs Monday, retreated yesterday. Closing prices were down the daily limit in most positions on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

Since 1976, rising interest rates have lopped $25 billion off the market value of bonds that individuals own, Kevin Hurley of Chase Econometric Associates said yesterday. In a special study he wrote for the Bala Cynwyd, Pa., forecasting firm, he warned that such losses in wealth typically preceded a slowdown in consumer spending.

WASHINGTON, March 6 State Department officials vowed today to continue working for a United Nations solution in South-West Africa, but they said privately that they were deeply discouraged by South Africa's rejection of the cease-fire.

Citicorp, in an apparent effort to prepare the market for additional issues of long-term debt, sought yesterday to convince bank analysts that only debt with maturities of 15 years or more should be considered part of capital.

The telephones started ringing early in many New York law firms yesterday. The divorced and the soon-to-be-divorced were calling; they wanted to know what the United States Supreme Court's landmark ruling on alimony Monday meant for them.

Tom Owens grew up in New York, played at LaSalle Academy in Manhattan and at the University of South Carolina and enjoyed stardom in both places. His pro basketball career was hardly as glittering until he landed with the Portland Trail Blazers in 1977 in a trade with the Houston Rockets.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 6 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission has removed the last legal barrier to the sale of the closed Federal Glass Company plant in Columbus to the Lancaster Colony Corporation.

A TWO-DAY symposium on business-government relations, held at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library here last week, was remark ably free of any antigovernment rhetoric on the part of the business executives present. Roger B. Smith, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, said United States business had to recognize that it "can never return to the laissez-faire capitalism of another time."

Dr. John H. Knowles, the president of the Rockefeller Foundation for the last seven years and an international medical leader, died yesterday at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. WASHINGTON, March 6--The John F. Kennedy Center and its National Black Commission announced today a new music project designed to showcase young black talent and the works of black composers seldom performed in the nation's concert halls.

Last week's mayoral primary election in Chicago brought a ray of spring cheer to students of American politics. Many are in despair over how few people now turn out to vote. That was one point less than the percentage who voted in the previous off-year election, in 1974, and ten points less than in 1962.

The list was prepared by the National Basketball Players' Association, which has estimated that the eligible group is earning more than $6 million in salaries this season.

JERUSALEM, March 12--Like an embarrassed guest helplessly witnessing a family quarrel, President Carter sat stoically today through a raucous session of the Israeli Parliament. A dozen members heckled and shouted angrily against peace talks, Prime Minister Menachem Begin, President Anwar el-Sadat and President Carter himself.
The United Federation of Teachers decided last night to seek binding arbitration to resolve a contract dispute over year-round salaries and pension rights for the city's 10,000 paraprofessionals.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 12--Despite the tragedy involving its member church, the People's Temple, in Guyana last November, the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) should not impose tighter membership policies, several denomination leaders said at the annual meeting of the administrative committee here.
ROME, March 12--Pope John Paul II, meeting today with leaders of world Jewish organizations, called for "a fraternal dialogue and fruitful cooperation" between the Roman Catholic Church and Jews.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 12-- Luis Herrera Campins assumed the presidency of Venezuela today in a peaceful transition of power that consolidates the democratic tradition of this oilproducing country.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 12--One of these days, the New York Yankees are going to find a majorleague rival they can beat in spring training. But it didn't happen today at Fort Lauderdale Stadium, where the Yankees lost a 2-0 decision to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Nowhere is the skill of governmental imagemakers more evident than in the titles they have invented for themselves. Years ago, one spoke of "press agent," "publicist" or the slightly derogatory "flack." But before long, the business had become elevated to a profession and its name was elevated to "public relations." In time, even that term lost its sheen and the shorthand version--"p.r."--came to imply, well, exaggeration.

MADISON, Wis., March 14--The editor of The Progressive magazine today accused the Department of Justice of having made "a sweeping attack on the First Amendment rights of the American people."

THE United States Trust Company, which manages in excess of $15 billion of personal and institutional wealth, has turned its attention to "collectibles" among other nontraditional stores of value.

WASHINGTON, March 15--The House of Representatives approved another rise in the public debt limit today, but only after narrowly beating back a strong challenge from increasingly confident supporters of a balanced budget.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 White the Boston Red Sox stayed busy by once more taking out their New York frustrations on the Mets, not a creature was stirring elsewhere today as the midnight deadline approached for interleague trades in baseball.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 15 A delegation of government officials and businessmen from Long Island brought to Rhode Island yesterday their dream of a bridge across the eastern end of Long Island Sound.

THE New York Book Fair, the annual meeting ground for small press publishers here and abroad that has provided New York with a lively series of gatherings in the last five years, has postponed its 1979 autumn fair until next spring. The postponement will give the fair people extra time to plan.
When he announced his coming encyclical last Sunday, Pope John Paul II said it contained thoughts that "have been of maturing in my mind during the years of my priestly and episcopal service."
Renee Buse, editor and writer, died of emphysema yesterday at Doctors Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

ATLANTA Gov. George Busbee is sitting pretty. Owing to constitutional reform, he's the first Georgia governor in modern times to have a second four-year term. His $2.7-billion budget will be balanced and largely unchanged by the Legislature.

WASHINGTON In 1940, Frank Perdue joined his father's chicken business on Maryland's Eastern Shore. They had one employee but many good ideas and a lot of drive. Today, that family operation employs 3,800 people and markets millions of tender chickens. But Frank says that if he were starting out in business now, he'd never make it: A fledgling operation stalls before it can shift out of first gear.
THE George Tomov Yugoslav Folkdance Ensemble, which appeared at the Theater of the Riverside Church on Wednesday, has a great deal going for it.

THE all-volunteer Army will be starting its latest recruiting advertising campaign next month against a background of increased agitation in high places for a return of the draft and a longer-than-usual shortfall in meeting recruiting quotas.

David M. Culver, president of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., will become chief executive officer of the big Canadian aluminum company on July 1, bringing to an end an uninterrupted period of control by the Davis family. For Mr. Culver, ascension to the top slot means the retirement of Nathanael V. Davis after 32 years as the head of Alcan.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) Inventories held by the nation's businesses surged by $5.4 billion, or 1.4 percent, in January from the monthearlier level, the Commerce Department said today. The rise in December had been a modest $2.8 billion, or seven-tenths of 1 percent.

WASHINGTON, March 15 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. will not give up his minority leader's post in "the foreseeable future," even though he is expected to formally announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination by July, the Senator's new campaign chairman said today.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 15 Nigeria, still smarting from an overambitious pricing program in 1977, is reacting warily to the round of oil price increases that have swept the world following the December cutoff of Iranian supplies.

That attitude, expressed in a recent interview, is still not the norm, but it is also not unusual. Many widows no longer regard remarriage as a priority, and a surprising number have not only accepted the return to single life, but have chosen to remain in it.

The Federal Government filed three lawsuits against Citibank yesterday in a complex dispute concerning $18.5 million in contracts to construct public buildings. The suits are seeking $3 million in damages.

JUNEAU, Alaska, March 15 (AP) Their boots lost and with only a few apples and onions and some Tang breakfast drink, a man and his three teenage children survived in subfreezing temperatures for more than a month after their sailboat ran aground on an island.

WASHINGTON, March 15--The Carter Administration is naturally pleased with the outcome of the President's mission to the Middle East, and is now pressing its diplomatic momentum abroad and its political advantage at home.
The Department of Commerce plans to intensify its efforts to attract more United States apparel and textile manufactures to the world export market, a department official said yesterday.

Dr. Louis Carp, consultant surgeon to Goldwater Memorial Hospital and Nyack Hospital, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the City Athletic Club. He was 86 years old and lived at 1 Sherman Square in New York City.

Effective May 1, Citibank will raise the monthly fee on its special checking accounts by 50 cents to $1.25 and the per-check fee by 5 cents to 20 cents, the bank announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15 Government prosecutors today indicated for the first time in open court that L. Patrick Gray 3d, the former Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, may never be tried on charges that he ordered bureau agents to enter private homes and offices illegally.

BOSTON, March 15 Calling Virginia Wade's behavior "unsportsmanlike," Rosie Casals pulled no punches tonight after her second-round loss to Miss Wade in the $150,000 women's professional tennis tournament at Boston University's Walter Brown Arena.

ROME, March 15 Pope John Paul II today solemnly proclaimed the intention of the Roman Catholic Church to serve more effectively as "the guardian of freedom" in a world where, he said injustice and a decline in the observance of moral values pose a "threat to all people of good will."

The announcement that CBS Inc.'s first-quarter earnings are expected to be down as much as 50 percent took much of Wall Street by surprise--not because earnings are likely to be lower, but because they are likely to be down by much more than the company had previously suggested.

WASHINGTON, March 15 Driven in part by events in the Middle East, the Government's spending this year and next year will be higher than the sums forecast by President Carter in his January budget, the Administration said today.

FROM an ebullient and exhaustive one-man dissertation on the sex life of the salmon to a spectacular puppet version of the story of St. Francis, New York theater this weekend offers the venturesome showgoer a banquet of tastes, visions and sensations. Broadway has its "Sweeney Todd" and Off Broadway its "Elephant Man," but at the moment the most unusual and unconventional theater is mostly Off Off Broadway.

WASHINGTON, March 15 After 15 months of agonizing labor, the National Commission on Neighborhoods gave birth today to a huge report calling for new government and business policies to aid urban neighborhoods.

The pilot of a British Airways Concorde reported yesterday that his airliner and a small private aircraft had missed each other by 100 feet vertically and 300 yards horizontally at a point 23 miles east of Kennedy International Airport.

TOKYO, March 15 (AP) Japan posted a trade surplus of $375.6 millian last month, compared with a deficit of $1.4 billion in January and a surplus of $1.6 billion in February 1978, the Finance Ministry announced today in a preliminary report.

The National Iranian Oil Company has signed several long-term contracts to sell crude oil at prices well below those recently paid in the open market, according to traders in New York.

Expansion 4 Years Old, Strong The economic recovery turned 4 years old this month, making it one of the longest business expansions on record. But economists who follow business cycles say the unusual length of the current growth phase does not by itself mean that a downturn is near.

Have these three figures anything in common?

"Think what it would cost in California! Three times as much. And for $80 a month, you can hire a maid or cook."

THE Masters, the congenial "company of friends" that Bobby Jones and Clifford Roberts established in 1934, inspires an abiding affection and admiration among the likes of Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer, Ben Hogan, Sam Snead, Gene Sarazen and a long line of other great golfers. Its effect on newcomers though, is something else.
CAMDEN, Ark., April 8 (AP)--At least 23 persons were injured and about 50 homes destroyed today when a tornado touched down in this southern Arkansas community, state officials said.

The Marshall Chess Club international tournament was the setting for a fine triumph for International Master Michael Rhode, a 19-year-old Yale student, who not only captured the first prize but also achieved his first grandmaster norm.

MIAMI, April 9--Five persons were killed in a head on collision on a busy twolane highway leading to the Florida Keys last night. The 30-mile stretch of Route 1 from Florida City to Key Largo is known as being the scene of a high number of fatal auto accidents.

Gak Kyu Choi, South Korea's Minister of Commerce and Industry, said yesterday that his country planned to reduce its growing dependence on imports from Japan by, among other things, shifting to exports from the United States.

HONG KONG, April 9--Sir Kenneth Fung, one of Hong Kong's leading businessmen and civic patrons, has been invited to return to his native village in China this week to reopen a private school and library that his family sponsored for poor local youths for years before the Cultural Revolution.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)--The House of Representatives voted today to suspend aid to Syria, which was criticized in debate as a radical nation trying to destroy President Carter's Middle East peace effort.

A group of teachers from Inner London visited two grade schools in Brooklyn yesterday. They agreed that the New York practice of publishing school reading scores, without reference to social circumstances, "is not something we would like" and is likely to "distort the public image of a school."

Dr. Lionel A. Walford, a marine biologist and former director of the Sandy Hook Marine Laboratory of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in Highlands, N.J., died of cancer yesterday at a nursing home in nearby Atlantic Highlands. He was 73 years old and lived in Rumson.

SIMPLE substances that may be the brain's natural means of controlling anxiety have been discovered recently in the course of research that is opening a whole new realm of understanding of the chemistry of emotion. The komitehs of revolutionary justice are working round the clock in Iran, executing the Shah's ministers and agents for crimes of state and violations of divine law. BERKELEY, Calif., April 9--People who live downwind from the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver have substantially higher cancer rates than Denver-area residents who are not exposed to the plant's plutonium emissions, according to a report made public today by the director of the health deparment of Jefferson County, where Rocky Flats is situated.

LONDON--The expression "labor movement" is a general and emotional term that evokes certain ideas: the fight against poverty, hunger and degradation; the raising up of working people from their status as mere labor, as an abstraction, a factor of production; a recognition of their equal dignity and pride in their function. The humanitarian purpose of the labor movement gave it the moral power of a crusade.

Mayor Koch is seeking, for the first time, to hire managers from private realestate agencies to handle the vast amount of property the city has acquired through foreclosures.

Shareholders of the Allstate Enterprises Stock Fund, meeting yesterday in Northbrook, Ill., approved a merger of their fund into the W.L. Morgan Growth Fund, a member of the Vanguard Group of investment companies.
A clash between striking teamsters and the police injured 14 strikers and 11 officers yesterday as a Brooklyn dairy made an effort to bring in raw milk through massed pickets.

ON plans of some of the great English country houses, there was often a room marked "flowers," where cut flowers from the garden were arranged and set in vases. These days, shrinking city apartments and efficiently planned houses don't have rooms set aside for such activities. Florists usually do the flower arranging, and often the vase is tossed out with the faded flowers.

Six striking school-bus drivers, attempting to block nonunion drivers from leaving a Queens garage to transport handicapped children to school, were arrested yesterday and charged with inciting to riot after a melee with the police. Union officials said several bus drivers had been injured, but the police said there had been only one.

SPRING has really arrived when even the cracks in city pave ments start sprouting grass. GENEVA, Thursday, April 12 The United States and the world's other leading industrialized countries, after more than five years of tough bargaining, finally brought negotiations to liberalize world trade to a successful conclusion early this morning by formally endorsing a 99-nation agreement. They acted dospite a bitter 11th-hour attack by developing countries charging the pact did too little for the world's poor.

FARMERS arrive at the Bronx Terminal Market at 4 in the morning, park on a large triangle of concrete behind the white Art Deco-style buildings and set out their flats of flowers, vegetable seedlings and house plants on the paving. It is agreeable to be reminded that New York is still a market town and that people still grow things around its edges.

A CITY balcony is as much a predicament as it is a prize. What plants will survive the extremes of light, shade and wind? How do you furnish such a tiny space? Horticulturists at Longwood Gardens in Kennett Square, Pa., took up the urban challenge and built five balconies to show apartment dwellers what could be done.

ATLANTA, April 11 The President of the National Bank of Georgia, in his annual address to shareholders and in a separate discussion with reporters today, sought to reshape the bank's image and move the institution from under the cloud of numerous investigations arising out of the earlier presidency of Bert Lance.

Comprehensive and up-to-date descriptions of bidding, written by a player of the highest rank, have been relatively rare in the literature of the game. A notable addition to this short series is "Standard Bidding," by Bill Root, this country's leading teacher.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 11 Yusufu K. Lule, a 67-year-old academic who describes himself as apolitical, announced here tonight that he would assume the presidency of a provisional Ugandan Government.
Marine Midland Banks Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings in the first quarter nearly doubled from the yearearlier level.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The leader of a National Academy of Sciences panel studying the health risks of saccharin told Congress today that he now believed the artificial sweetener should be phased out within three years.

WASHINGTON, April 11 The Carter Administration today embraced the contract settlement reached last night by the teamsters and the trucking industry, proclaiming it to be within the President's wage guidelines and, therefore, a contribution to the anti-inflation fight.

WASHINGTON, April 11 The Justice Department has been investigating the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation for more than a year and expects to decide soon whether to prosecute the company for dumping toxic chemicals in the Love Canal site at Niagara Falls, N.Y.

CHICAGO, April 11 A Cook County Circuit Court judge issued a temporary restraining order today forbidding the Illinois Department of Mental Health to destroy any records pertaining to surgery in the 1950's and 1960's in which the adrenal glands of mental patients were allegedly removed in "unauthorized and secret experiments."
Harold P. Borer, a retired general manager of the Cunard Line, died April 3 in Ponte Vedre Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

The International Business Machines Corporation, the leading producer in its field, with about half of the computer systems market, reported yesterday a 13.2 percent increase in first-quarter profits on a 19.5 percent rise in gross income.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Senator Herman E. Talmadge has agreed to admit to what were described as minor violations of Senate rules but will contest fully the major allegations of financial misconduct lodged against him, his attorney said today.

ADAMS, Ind., April 11 (UPI) Pfc. Robert Garwood of the Marines says he waited for years until he found a nonVietnamese to smuggle out of Vietnam a message that eventually led to his return home after nearly 14 years.
Members of a Trans World Airlines crew are scheduled to give their first public accounting today of the nearly disastrous, 30,000-foot dive of a Boeing 727 jet over Michigan last week.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 11 (AP) Troops and aircraft of the Nicaraguan National Guard attacked the northern city of Esteli today in a drive to dislodge rebels who have held most of the town for six days, fleeing refugees and Red Cross workers reported.

FRANKFURT, April 11 (AP) Net monetary reserves of the West German central bank fell by 1.4 billion marks, or about $727 million, to 85.9 billion marks, or $45.2 billion, in the week ended April 7, the Deutsche Bundesbank said in its weekly statement today.

After having failed a fire test, a metal clip used in the installation of ceilings has been replaced by spot-welding at the new 702-bed Veterans Administration hospital in the Bronx, and officials said yesterday that they hoped to be able to move from the old building by late summer or early fall.
John Roland, a co-anchor of the 10 P.M. news program on WNEW-TV, Channel 5, has become the newscast's new anchor.

Two young trespassers who had been drinking beer atop the mausoleum of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt have been directed to put in two weeks of hard labor next month cleaning up the 21-acre Vanderbilt family section of Moravian Cemetery on Staten Island.
The Gulf Oil Chemicals Company, a division of the Gulf Oil Corporation, announced that it planned to purchase a 30 percent equity interest in the Taita Chemical Company of Taiwan.

ONE of the most appealing classics of American painting in the present century is the double portrait of "The Artist and His Mother" by Arshile Gorky that reposes in the permanent collection of the Whitney Museum of American Art. In this painting are conjoined many of the emotions that gave Gorky's life its special quality.

COOK UNITED INC., a Middle Western chain of discount stores that has long been considered a merger candidate, suddenly has two suitors. The company's shares rose yesterday in active trading after word reached Wall Street that there was interest in a takeover. Cook closed at 7 5/8 up 5/8, on volume of 128,900 shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 12--Frank Cossano, a 31-year-old salesman from Valley Stream, L.I., was released in his own custody today after being charged on Wednesday with the kidnapping of his estranged wife, Margaret, 26.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)--Amtrak said today that it was testing a new French-built turbine engine that gets 41 percent more power than engines now used in Amtrak's turboliner trains. The engine would allow Amtrak to use one engine instead of two to power its turbine trains, resulting in a 25 percent fuel saving. The new engines arebuilt by the Turbomeca concern of Brevets, France.
Mixed reactions have greeted this week's message to priests by Pope John Paul II reaffirming mandatory celibacy and discouraging priests from forsaking the clergy in order to marry.

LOS ANGELES--Black leadership has come disproportionately from two highly atypical groups--descendants of blacks free before the Civil War and West Indian immigrants. LONDON, April 12 (Reuters)--A Japanese Buddhist leader, Nikkyo Niwano, has been awarded what is described as the "Nobel prize for religion." The award was set up by John Templeton, an American banker.

The New York State Court of Appeals ruled last week that a prison guard cannot be fired merely for belonging to the Ku Klux Klan. It is somewhat unsettling to think of a Klansman guarding black and Hispanic prisoners, but the court's adherence to the right of free association cannot be faulted.

A COUPLE of weeks ago, CBS had a TV movie about young mentally retarded lovers. "No Other Love" starred Richard Thomas and Julie Kavner. Tonight at 9, ABC has a TV movie about young mentally retarded lovers.

The Chemical New York Corporation yesterday reported first-quarter operating earnings of $30.7 million, an 11.2 percent increase over its operating earnings in the comparable period of 1978. INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 12--A Trans World Airlines pilot whose Boeing 727 went into a twisting plunge over Michigan April 4 testified today that it was only when he saw the moon glowing in the distance that he knew with certainty that he had pulled out of the perilous dive.

A statewide tenant organization announced yesterday that it would initiate court action to stop landlords from collecting fuel surcharges in rent-stabilized apartments in New York City and from increasing rents where leases are already in effect.
BRUNSWICK, Ga., April 12--Jimmy Carter, embarking on a 10-day vacation, arrived here this morning and promptly disappeared from sight.

LONDON, April 12 (AP)--Retail prices in Britain rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, matching February's gain, the Department of Employment reported today. The department said that prices were up 9.8 percent from March 1978. It was the fifth consecutive month that the year-to-year increase grew and was the biggest such gain since January 1978.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 12 (UPI)--The director of Pertamina, the state-owned oil company, said today that the Mobil Corporation was ready to market Indonesian liquefied natural gas produced by the Arun natural gas field in north Sumatra.
A photograph of Idi Amin was taken down at Uganda House yesterday, and the headquarters of the Ugandan mission to the United Nations was handed over to representatives of the new Government.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 12 (UPI) --Vice President Mondale, who is on a tour of northern Europe, held talks with Icelandic leaders today.

Commercial and industrial loans on the books of the major New York banks rose $168 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the comparable week last year, the increase amounted to only $13 million.

In an example of what might be called "impact rehabilitation," a builder is restoring abandoned buildings that fill nearly the entire south side of a block of Harlem's West 135th Street and is turning them into modern apartments.
Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings of the Chrysler Corporation's debentures and commercial paper yesterday, citing the auto manufacturer's "recent adverse operating results."

After four days of declining prices and rising interest rates, the credit markets yesterday recovered slightly as they waited to see if the Federal Reserve tightens monetary policy at its Open Market Committee meeting next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 12--The Carter Administration's top authority on communications urged the Federal Communications Commission today to adopt a new licensing procedure for radio and television broadcasting that could give preference to minorities.

GENEVA, April 12--Major producer and consumer countries of natural rubber agreed here today on the key elements of a market stabilizing accord they expect to conclude before August.

ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, April 12--The path that leads for 20 minutes from a country road through fields of stubble and sparse woods turns sharply to the left near the malodorous remains of a cow that stepped on a landmine a day or two ago. Then the path descends sharply toward a narrow stream.

ROME, April 14--Pope John Paul II, in an essay published yesterday, expressed his dismay over terrorism and violence, especially in Italy, and called for social analysis of their causes.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 14 (Reuters)--Heavy fighting erupted today near the Thai border between Vietnamese-led forces of the new Government in Cambodia and forces loyal to the ousted regime of Pol Pot.
SAPELO ISLAND, Ga., April 14 (AP)--Despite a threat of rain, President Carter ventured out this afternoon for a picnic today that was organized by his daughter, Amy.

HARTFORD IF a Harrisburg-type nuclear accident ever happened at Waterford, the First Selectman of neighboring East Lyme could be reached through a beeper in his home, and communi cations could be maintained through the eightchannel scanner and 30-watt transceiver or through the four-channel portable scanner that he has at his disposal.

The engagement of Mary Francis Henningsen to Christopher Minturn Collins has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Henningsen Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Minturn Post Collins of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Collins.
MONTEREY PARK, Calif., April 14 --Sixteen-year-old Tracy Caulkins of Nashville, the world's best swimmer in 1978, is on her way to becoming the world's best swimmer in 1979.

WALTER F. MURPHY, a professor of jurisprudence at Princeton, has tried--with only partial success--to produce in "The Vicar of Christ" a synthesis of the American dream and the definitive Catholic novel.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 14 (AP) --Rhodesian planes attacked black guerrilla bases in Zambia today, military officials announced, and inside Rhodesia 90 guerrillas were reported killed in some of the heaviest fighting of the war.

ATLANTIC CITY WELL aware that every municipality in New Jersey is looking over its shoulder, the State Su preme Court is considering an appeal of a decision by Judge Philip A. Gruccio of Superior Court that permitted Atlantic City to bypass the 5 percent "cap" law and hand out state-arbitrated salary increases.

The engagement of Ellen Louise Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hall of Rye, N.Y., to Kevin John McEllin, son of Elizabeth McEllin of Waltham, Mass., and John McEllin of Brighton, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Plans have been made for an Aug. 4 wedding at the Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Rye.

Mr. and Mrs. Lucian Jack Knight of Huntington, W.Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Donna Marie Knight, to First Lieut. John Eric Davis, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Matthew Davis of Glen Cove, L.I. Plans have been made for a May 12 wedding at the Main Post Chapel, Fort Bragg, N.C., where the prospective bridegroom is stationed.

NEWARK DESPITE a last-minute influx of additional state aid, the laying off of municipal em ployees and major shifts in spending, the City Council in this financially and otherwise beleaguered city has adopted a budget for the 1979 fiscal year that increases the local propertytax rate by 32 points.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Future output of Saudi Arabian oil will be far less than predicted, adding urgency to the need for revised American energy policies, a report released by a Senate subcommittee said today.
EAST BERLIN, April 14--East Germany today announced new restrictions on foreign journalists, forbidding them to interview people without official permission.

STORRS ROBERT MOTHERWELL is not easily designated a Connecticut artist, and his work, alighting at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, looks like some large, exotic bird blown off its accustomed course.
TOKYO, April 14 (AP)--Takako Kiyomoto of Japan scored a 3-underpar 72 today to draw away from two coleaders with a three-stroke lead after the second round of a $70,000 women's golf tournament.

Like most other prices, the rates charged by hotels and motels across the United States are rising this year. It is still possible in some areas, however, to find decent though modest accommodations for as low as $10 a person a night, $15 for two and $17.50 for a family of four.

YAPHANK AT the height of concern over the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania, it was estimated that more than 20,000 people had evacuated the area voluntarily, in addition to pregnant women and young children.

VAUGHN, N.M., April 14 (UPI)--A broken roller bearing on a Santa Fe Railway freight car was blamed today for a 41-car derailment and a fire in a sparsely populated area of eastern New Mexico. The fire, which erupted when one of the cars loaded with lubricating oil burst into flames, was still burning late today.

Collectors of old-time paper money will be happy to hear of the recent new edition of Hodges's "American Bank Note Safe-Guard," first published in New York in 1863 by Edward M. Hodges, and a valuable reference work for all specialists in this field.
AT the height of her astounding career, the actress Sarah Bernhardt had received every honor and award possible, including Oscar Wilde's lasting appellation, "the Divine Sarah."

THE New York property tax system is in turmoil. Because of court-ordered changes in assessment practices, municipalities are hurrying to revaluate property, and shuddering as they find that revaluation can bring with it large increases in residential property taxes.
